I should've called in sick...waking up and thinking it's Friday (on a Tuesday!!!) was my first clue. Then I spent the majority of the day packing computers to ship to Montreal. I swear I was getting dizzy on the "fumes" from the packing tape. Didn't leave work until 4:00pm. Thought all was well...I'd ride Bart and read all the way to 24th stree instead of getting off downtown to transfer to the street car. I MUST stop thinking when on public transit!! My happiness ended shortly after entering the tunnel. The train halts & then you smell burning brakes. The operator comes on the P.A. system to announce he's going to shut the train down for a minute & a half. Everything goes pitch black (Rob - remember that "dream" I told you about regarding us sitting on Bart? I thought about that and started giggling my ass off). The lights came back on & the train starts moving...only to stop again. The operator comes back on to say that we're going to move slowly all the way to Embarcadero station. About two to three minutes after that the smell is back...and it's WORSE. The train starts filling up with smoke. And the operator's not saying a damn thing about it. A few people started to panic (which got me a little panicky). Another passenger came all the way from the front of the train to tell people to move several cars ahead where there was minimal to no smoke (I think I was in car 8 of 10). We finally pull into the station and as we're getting off, massive amounts of smoke starts filling the platform. Obviously I'm taking the street car. When I get to the Muni platform, it's all filled with smoke as well (that's how bad it was). The only highlight was that I only had to wait two minutes for my streetcar. I'm home...I'm cranky...and I smell like smoke. Please tell me it'll be better tomorrow?

My favorite is the haiku section. There you will find me down below the belt buckle hunting moose knuckle Her jeans betray her Tenth grade math, sixth period My first toe spotting. Father's Day was launched in Spokane, Washington, in June, 1910, by a woman by the name of Sonora Smart Dodd. Mrs. Dodd wanted a special day to honor her father, William Henry Jackson Smart (having thought of the idea for Father's Day while listening to a Mother's Day sermon in 1909). William Smart, a Civil War veteran, was widowed when his wife died in childbirth with their sixth child. Mr. Smart was left to raise the newborn and his other five children by himself. It was after Sonora became an adult that she realized the strength and selflessness her father had shown in raising his children as a single parent. She wanted her father to know how special he was to her. It was her father that made all the parental sacrifices and was, in the eyes of his daughter, a courageous, selfless, and loving man. Her father was born in June, so she chose to hold the first Father's Day celebration in Spokane, Washington on the 19th of June, 1910. In 1924 President Calvin Coolidge proclaimed the third Sunday in June as Father's Day. Roses are the Father's Day flowers: red to be worn for a living father and white if the father has died. Father's Day is a day of commemoration and celebration of Dad. It is a day to not only honor your father, but all men who have acted as a father figure in your life - whether as Stepfathers, Uncles, Grandfathers, or "Big Brothers."

Around the corner I have a friend, In this great city that has no end, Yet the days go by and weeks rush on, And before I know it, a year is gone. And I never see my old friends face, For life is a swift and terrible race, He knows I like him just as well, As in the days when I rang his bell. And he rang mine but we were younger then, And now we are busy, tired men. Tired of playing a foolish game, Tired of trying to make a name. "Tomorrow" I say! "I will call on Jim Just to show that I'm thinking of him." But tomorrow comes and tomorrow goes, And distance between us grows and grows. Around the corner, yet miles away, "Here's a telegram sir," "Jim died today." And that's what we get and deserve in the end. Around the corner, a vanished friend. - Author Unknown

I know I'm a drama queen...but something that happened today really made me realize how easily life can change in an instant. Danielle & I had gone to Walgreens (a block from the job). I didn't think too much of it because you always see cop cars in this area. As we were coming out, this man grabbed me & told me to get back inside because "they're about to start shooting." Like a dummy, I poked my head out of the door to see about 10 cop cars just a few doors down from where we were surrounding this car with guns drawn. I have never seen anything like that up close and personal in my life and was totally freaked out to say the least. Thankfully, they didn't end up having to shoot so we were able to leave the store with out further events occuring...but I can't get it out my head what I saw and what could've happened. Feeling VERY thankful right now...

People come into your life for a reason, a season, or a lifetime. When you figure out which it is, you know exactly what to do. When someone is in your life for a REASON , it is usually to meet a need you have expressed outwardly or inwardly. They have come to assist you through a difficulty, to provide you with guidance and support, to aid you physically, emotionally or spiritually.... They may seem like a Godsend, and they are. They are there for the reason you need them to be. Then, without any wrong doing on your part or an inconvenient time, this person will say or do something to bring the relationship to an end. Sometimes they die. Sometimes they walk away.... Sometimes they act up or out and force you to take a stand. What we must realize is that our need has been met, our desire fulfilled; their work is done. The prayer you sent up has been answered and it is now time to move on. When people come into your life for a SEASON , it is because your turn has come to share, grow, or learn. They may bring you an experience of peace or make you laugh. They may teach you something you have never done. They usually give you an unbelievable amount of joy. It is real, but...only for a season. LIFETIME relationships teach you lifetime lessons; those things you must build upon in order to have a solid emotional foundation. Your job is to accept the lesson, love the person/people (anyway); and put what you have learned to use in all other relationships and areas of your life.

This week I've been stuck. This "issue" with my friend just won't go away. I've been going back and forth all week second guessing my decision to end things & losing a lot of sleep over it. Tuesday morning, I purchased Iyanla Vanzant's, urlLink Yesterday I Cried . As I was reading it, I came to a part on closure... When you discover that something is broken, you must determine the cause of the break. In order to do that, you must open the thing, examine it, and find the origin of the break or malfunction. Once that is done, you must make a determination as to whether or not the thing is worth fixing. If you determine that the fixing is worth your effort, it must be done carefully. If, on the other hand, you decide that the thing is not worth fixing, you must get rid of it. You must throw it away, clean the place it once occupied, and when you are ready, find a suitable replacement. This is called "closure." I'm not ready to let go, even though I said goodbye (but that's because I thought he wanted nothing to do with me). I truly believe our friendship is worth fixing. I emailed him this afternoon asking him if he wanted me to leave him alone or if he wanted us to "fix it." I haven't heard from him...yet....

I was definitely glad to be out of the house as I think I would've just sat around and moped, feeling sorry for myself. My friends really took care of me this weekend, which is just what I needed. It's very hard to turn off my feelings and pretend nothing's wrong. The last time I talked to my friend was a week ago today. I sent him an email last Monday that he won't even respond too...which has made it hurt worse. I don't understand how someone can tell you they care about and appreciate you, but then treat you like the crap stuck on the bottom of their shoe. I'll be glad when I get to the point where I stop asking why... The garlic festival was fun! Lot's of good food, but too hot (got really dehydrated)!! I still reek of garlic...tasted a lot of good stuff...I will NEVER try garlic ice cream. There is something so wrong about the fact that it even exists. I'm going to make a point to go next year, but I'm definitely getting there when the doors open (soooo many people). Church was awesome (& packed) today. I tried to keep it together but my emotions were on over drive & every song the choir sang spoke to the issues going on in my life. So glad I was seeing Shrek afterwards (finally). I definitely needed something to make me laugh. It was a funny movie, but I think I liked the first one more. I don't get why people kept saying that Antonio Banderas' character (Puss-n-Boots) stole the show. The character was funny, but Donkey was much funnier. Can't wait until SpongBob comes out...then I can see it with my nieces when I go to Grand Rapids for Thanksgiving. That's going to be sooo much fun. Well....I know in time, things will get easier to deal with...I'm hoping this week goes by fast.

God....such a hard week. I am so thankful for and too the rest of my friends who've been so supportive of my "issues" (regarding the friend I recently said goodbye too). I posted the following over a month ago. I painfully ended a 3+ year friendship two days ago. It's one of the hardest things I've ever had to do, as I care for & love this person deeply. I keep re-reading this to remind myself it's okay to let go... People come into your life for a reason, a season, or a lifetime. When you figure out which it is, you know exactly what to do. When someone is in your life for a REASON , it is usually to meet a need you have expressed outwardly or inwardly. They have come to assist you through a difficulty, to provide you with guidance and support, to aid you physically, emotionally or spiritually.... They may seem like a Godsend, and they are. They are there for the reason you need them to be. Then, without any wrong doing on your part or an inconvenient time, this person will say or do something to bring the relationship to an end. Sometimes they die. Sometimes they walk away.... Sometimes they act up or out and force you to take a stand. What we must realize is that our need has been met, our desire fulfilled; their work is done. The prayer you sent up has been answered and it is now time to move on. When people come into your life for a SEASON , it is because your turn has come to share, grow, or learn. They may bring you an experience of peace or make you laugh. They may teach you something you have never done. They usually give you an unbelievable amount of joy. It is real, but...only for a season. LIFETIME relationships teach you lifetime lessons; those things you must build upon in order to have a solid emotional foundation. Your job is to accept the lesson, love the person/people (anyway); and put what you have learned to use in all other relationships and areas of your life.
